0: Prepare and process import and export documentation according to customs regulations, laws, or procedures.
Clear goods through customs and to their destinations for clients.
Pay, or arrange for payment of, taxes and duties on shipments.
Calculate duty and tariff payments owed on shipments.
Request or compile necessary import documentation, such as customs invoices, certificates of origin, and cargo-control documents.
Classify goods according to tariff coding system.
Stay abreast of changes in import or export laws or regulations by reading current literature, attending meetings or conferences, or conferring with colleagues.
Sign documents on behalf of clients, using powers of attorney.
Advise customers on import and export restrictions, tariff systems, insurance requirements, quotas, or other customs-related matters.
Post bonds for the products being imported or assist clients in obtaining bonds.
Quote duty and tax rates on goods to be imported, based on federal tariffs and excise taxes.
Arrange for transportation, warehousing, or product distribution of imported or exported products.
Monitor or trace the location of goods.
Confer with officials in various agencies to facilitate clearance of goods through customs and quarantine.
Inform importers and exporters of steps to reduce duties and taxes.
Obtain line releases for frequent shippers of low-risk commodities, high-volume entries, or multiple-container loads.
Provide advice on transportation options, types of carriers, or shipping routes.
Contract with freight forwarders for destination services.
Apply for tariff concessions or for duty drawbacks and other refunds.
Insure cargo against loss, damage, or pilferage.
Prepare papers for shippers to appeal duty charges.
1: Analyze training needs to develop new training programs or modify and improve existing programs.
Evaluate instructor performance and the effectiveness of training programs, providing recommendations for improvement.

Plan, develop, and provide training and staff development programs, using knowledge of the effectiveness of methods such as classroom training, demonstrations, on-the-job training, meetings, conferences, and workshops.
Confer with management and conduct surveys to identify training needs based on projected production processes, changes, and other factors.
Conduct orientation sessions and arrange on-the-job training for new hires.
Train instructors and supervisors in techniques and skills for training and dealing with employees.
Develop and organize training manuals, multimedia visual aids, and other educational materials.
Prepare training budget for department or organization.
Develop testing and evaluation procedures.
Conduct or arrange for ongoing technical training and personal development classes for staff members.
Review and evaluate training and apprenticeship programs for compliance with government standards.
2: Monitor and record food temperatures to ensure food safety.
Cook foodstuffs according to menus, special dietary or nutritional restrictions, or numbers of portions to be served.
Rotate and store food supplies.
Wash pots, pans, dishes, utensils, or other cooking equipment.
Apportion and serve food to facility residents, employees, or patrons.
Clean and inspect galley equipment, kitchen appliances, and work areas to ensure cleanliness and functional operation.
Clean, cut, and cook meat, fish, or poultry.
Direct activities of one or more workers who assist in preparing and serving meals.
Train new employees.
Take inventory of supplies and equipment.
Requisition food supplies, kitchen equipment, and appliances, based on estimates of future needs.
Bake breads, rolls, or other pastries.

0: Verify shipment compliance with relevant customs regulations and laws.
Prepare and submit accurate export declarations to customs authorities.
Negotiate with vendors to resolve discrepancies in freight bills or invoices.
Conduct site visits to inspect shipments and verify their contents.
Research and stay up-to-date on changes in trade laws, regulations, and policies.
Develop and maintain strong relationships with suppliers, logistics providers, and customers.
Coordinate with carriers and transportation companies to arrange for timely delivery.
Prepare and submit necessary documentation for customs clearance, including bills of lading and commercial invoices.
Investigate and resolve issues related to customs clearance, including detained shipments.
Monitor and track shipments through various stages of transit.
Provide expertise and guidance to clients on customs procedures and regulations.
Prepare and submit responses to inquiries from customs authorities or regulatory agencies.
Maintain accurate records and files related to client shipments and transactions.
Identify and mitigate potential risks associated with customs transactions, such as sanctions or tariffs.
Facilitate communication between clients, logistics providers, and other stakeholders involved in international trade.
Comply with all relevant laws, regulations, and industry standards governing customs brokerage services.
Analyze data and trends to identify opportunities for process improvements and efficiency gains.
Provide training and support to new employees or clients on customs procedures and regulations.
Maintain certification and registration as a Customs Broker, including ensuring compliance with industry standards and best practices.
Develop and implement contingency plans in the event of disruptions to customs services or procedures.
Stay informed about emerging trends, technologies, and innovations in international trade and customs brokerage.
1: Develop, implement, and evaluate organizational training programs to enhance employee skills and performance.
Design and deliver specialized training sessions for high-priority projects or initiatives, ensuring alignment with business objectives.
Identify training needs through analysis of employee performance data, feedback, and industry trends.
Collaborate with subject matter experts to create engaging and relevant training content, incorporating adult learning principles.
Create and manage training budgets, forecasting expenses, and tracking ROI to optimize resource allocation.
Facilitate workshops, seminars, and coaching sessions for employees at various levels of the organization.
Conduct needs assessments and gap analyses to determine training requirements, identifying areas for improvement.
Develop and maintain relationships with vendors and suppliers to procure training materials, equipment, and services.
Evaluate the effectiveness of training programs through surveys, assessments, and follow-up evaluations.
Create and disseminate communication materials, such as newsletters and announcements, to promote training initiatives and updates.
Coordinate with stakeholders to align training programs with business strategies, ensuring seamless integration into organizational goals.
2: Prepare high-quality meals in accordance with menu plans and dietary restrictions.
Maintain a clean and sanitary kitchen environment, adhering to food safety standards.
Operate cooking equipment such as ovens, stoves, and fryers safely and efficiently.
Chop, dice, and prepare ingredients according to recipe instructions.
Monitor and control food temperatures during preparation and service.
Inventory kitchen supplies and report any discrepancies to management.
Implement food safety protocols, including proper handling and storage of perishable items.
Clean and sanitize utensils, equipment, and workstations after each use.
Responsible for the ordering and inventory of food and beverages.
Maintain accurate records of menu items, ingredients, and food costs.
Manage cash handling and make change for customers in a timely manner.
Develop and maintain relationships with suppliers to ensure consistent delivery of quality ingredients.
